paper_abstract: We consider the first-order theory of the monoid P (A*) of languages over a finite or infinite alphabet A (with at least two letters) endowed solely with concatenation lifted to sets: no set theoretical predicate or function, no constant. Coding a word u by the submonoid u* it generates, we prove that the operation (u *, v *) -> (uv)* and the predicate {(u *, X) vertical bar epsilon is an element of X, u is an element of X} are definable in < P (A*); ; = > This allows to interpret the second-order theory of < A*; ; = > in the first-order theory of < P (A*); ; = > and prove the undecidability of the Pi(8) fragment of this last theory. These results involve technical difficulties witnessed by the logical complexity of the obtained definitions: the above mentioned predicates are respectively Delta(5) and Delta(7).
paper_title: Logical Theory of the Monoid of Languages over a Non Tally Alphabet
